item.title: Visualizing How a Kernel Draws a Smooth Line
Gradient Ascent: Finding Uphill Routes for my Long Walks
item.description: An old back injury makes it so that walking uphill is much more comfortable for me than walking downhill. A programmatic search for uphill routes reveals how strict constraints and “greedy” decisions can lead to sub-optimal results.

item.title: Avoiding Variance on my Morning Commute
item.description: Sacrificing value for certainty is a common tradeoff in life. Is this what I was (accidentally) doing when I started walking the first part of my daily commute instead of taking the subway? Some historical MTA data can help answer that question.

item.title: Pushing Google's Autocorrect to the Limit
item.description: Everyone makes errors sometimes when hastily typing a query into a search bar, and most of the time Google is able to recognize your mistake and offer a suggestion. But what is this algorithm’s breaking point? How badly can you mis-type a word before even Google doesn’t know what you mean anymore?

item.title: About Me!
item.description: Hello! My name is Walker Harrison and I’m a data scientist. I graduated from Columbia University in 2014 with a double major in mathematics and creative writing. After working in marketing and business development roles for several years at IBM and The Practical Dev, I got my Master’s degree in statistics from Duke University. Since 2018 I have been working as a quantitative analyst for the New York Yankees. This website will be used primarily to publish blogposts that explore some of the ways statistics intersect with our everyday lives.

item.title: Consulting
item.description: If you or your company need assistance somewhere along the data analysis pipeline, I may be a good fit. I have experience in data extraction and retrieval, including web scraping of both static and dynamic content. I am well versed in SQL and have set up relational databases for various personal projects, including ones that required “big data.” I do most of my data cleaning and manipulation in R, and enjoy helping others wrangle their data via Stack Overflow questions.
